intro: Chamaesyce grisea, commonly known as gray sandmat, is a low-growing annual plant native to the southwestern United States and northern Mexico. It belongs to the family Portulacaceae and is characterized by its succulent, fleshy leaves that are often covered in a fine, grayish-white pubescence. The plant produces small, yellow flowers that bloom in late spring to early summer. It thrives in sandy or gravelly soils and is drought-tolerant, making it well adapted to arid environments. Its botanical features make it a hardy and resilient species often found in disturbed or open habitats.
